083/**
084 *  Library of utility methods that are useful when dealing with Strings. <br>
085 *  <br>Parts of the code were adopted from the class
086 *  <code>org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils</code> and modified to match the
087 *  requirements of this project. In particular, these are the methods
088 *  <ul>
089 *  <li>{@link #abbreviate(CharSequence, int) abbreviate()}</li>
090 *  <li>{@link #capitalize(CharSequence) capitalize()}</li>
091 *  <li>{@link #escapeHTML(CharSequence) escapeHTML()} in both versions</li>
092 *  <li>{@link #isEmpty(CharSequence) isEmpty()}</li>
093 *  <li>{@link #isNotEmpty(CharSequence) isNotEmpty()}</li>
094 *  <li>{@link #repeat(CharSequence, int) repeat()}</li>
095 *  <li>{@link #uncapitalize(CharSequence) uncapitalize()}</li>
096 *  <li>{@link #unescapeHTML(CharSequence) unescapeHTML()} in both versions</li>
097 *  </ul>
098 *
099 *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
100 *  @version $Id: StringUtils.java 1076 2023-10-03 18:36:07Z tquadrat $
101 *  @since 0.0.3
102 *
103 *  @UMLGraph.link
104 */
105@SuppressWarnings( {"ClassWithTooManyMethods", "OverlyComplexClass"} )
106@ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: StringUtils.java 1076 2023-10-03 18:36:07Z tquadrat $" )
107@UtilityClass
108public final class StringUtils
109{
110        /*---------------*\
111    ====** Inner Classes **====================================================
112        \*---------------*/
113    /**
114     *  The clipping mode that is used for the method
115     *  {@link StringUtils#pad(CharSequence,int,char,Padding,Clipping)}
116     *
117     *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
118     *  @version $Id: StringUtils.java 1076 2023-10-03 18:36:07Z tquadrat $
119     *  @since 0.0.3
120     *
121     *  @UMLGraph.link
122     */
123    @SuppressWarnings( "InnerClassTooDeeplyNested" )
124    @ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: StringUtils.java 1076 2023-10-03 18:36:07Z tquadrat $" )
125    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
126    public static enum Clipping
127    {
128            /*------------------*\
129        ====** Enum Declaration **=============================================
130            \*------------------*/
131        /**
132         *  If an input String is already longer than the target length, it
133         *  will be returned unchanged.
134         */
135        CLIPPING_NONE
136        {
137            /**
138             *  {@inheritDoc}
139             */
140            @Override
141            protected final String clip( final CharSequence input, final int length ) { return input.toString(); }
142        },
143
144        /**
145         *  If an input String is longer than the target length, it will be
146         *  just shortened to that length.
147         */
148        CLIPPING_CUT
149        {
150            /**
151             *  {@inheritDoc}
152             */
153            @Override
154            protected final String clip( final CharSequence input, final int length )
155            {
156                final var retValue = (
157                    input.length() > length ? input.subSequence( 0, length ) :
158                    input).toString();
159
160                //---* Done *--------------------------------------------------
161                return retValue;
162            }   //  clip()
163        },
164
165        /**
166         *  If an input String is longer than the target length, it will be
167         *  abbreviated to that length, by calling
168         *  {@link StringUtils#abbreviate(CharSequence, int)}
169         *  with that String. The minimum length for the padded String is 4.
170         */
171        CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE
172        {
173            /**
174             *  {@inheritDoc}
175             */
176            @Override
177            protected final String clip( final CharSequence input, final int length ) { return abbreviate( input, length ); }
178        },
179
180        /**
181         *  If an input String is longer than the target length, it will be
182         *  abbreviated to that length, by calling
183         *  {@link StringUtils#abbreviateMiddle(CharSequence, int)}
184         *  with that String. The minimum length for the padded String is 5.
185         */
186        CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE_MIDDLE
187        {
188            /**
189             *  {@inheritDoc}
190             */
191            @Override
192            protected final String clip( final CharSequence input, final int length ) { return abbreviateMiddle( input, length ); }
193        };
194
195            /*---------*\
196        ====** Methods **======================================================
197            \*---------*/
198        /**
199         *  Clips the given input String.
200         *
201         *  @param  input   The input String.
202         *  @param  length  The target length.
203         *  @return The result String.
204         */
205        protected abstract String clip( final CharSequence input, final int length );
206    }
207    //  enum Clipping
208
209    /**
210     *  The padding mode that is used for the methods
211     *  {@link StringUtils#pad(CharSequence,int,char,Padding,boolean)}
212     *  and
213     *  {@link StringUtils#pad(CharSequence,int,char,Padding,Clipping)}
214     *
215     *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
216     *  @version $Id: StringUtils.java 1076 2023-10-03 18:36:07Z tquadrat $
217     *  @since 0.0.5
218     *
219     *  @UMLGraph.link
220     */
221    @SuppressWarnings( "InnerClassTooDeeplyNested" )
222    @ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: StringUtils.java 1076 2023-10-03 18:36:07Z tquadrat $" )
223    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
224    public static enum Padding
225    {
226            /*------------------*\
227        ====** Enum Declaration **=============================================
228            \*------------------*/
229        /**
230         *  The pad characters are distributed evenly at begin and end of the
231         *  string.
232         */
233        PADDING_CENTER
234        {
235            /**
236             *  {@inheritDoc}
237             */
238            @Override
239            protected final String pad( final CharSequence input, final int padSize, final char c )
240            {
241                final var rightSize = padSize / 2;
242                final var leftSize = padSize - rightSize;
243                final var retValue = padding( leftSize, c ) + input.toString() + padding( rightSize, c );
244
245                //---* Done *--------------------------------------------------
246                return retValue;
247            }   //  pad()
248        },
249
250        /**
251         *  The pad characters are added at the beginning of the string
252         *  (prefixing it).
253         */
254        PADDING_LEFT
255        {
256            /**
257             *  {@inheritDoc}
258             */
259            @Override
260            protected final String pad( final CharSequence input, final int padSize, final char c )
261            {
262                return padding( padSize, c ) + input.toString();
263            }   //  pad()
264        },
265
266        /**
267         *  The pad characters are added the end of the string (as a suffix).
268         */
269        PADDING_RIGHT
270        {
271            /**
272             *  {@inheritDoc}
273             */
274            @Override
275            protected final String pad( final CharSequence input, final int padSize, final char c )
276            {
277                return input.toString() + padding( padSize, c );
278            }   //  pad()
279        };
280
281            /*---------*\
282        ====** Methods **======================================================
283            \*---------*/
284        /**
285         *  Pads the given input String.
286         *
287         *  @param  input   The input String.
288         *  @param  padSize The pad size.
289         *  @param  c   The pad character.
290         *  @return The result String.
291         */
292        protected abstract String pad( final CharSequence input, final int padSize, final char c );
293
294        /**
295         *  <p>{@summary Returns padding using the specified pad character repeated to the
296          *  given length.}</p>
297         *  <br><code>
298         *  Padding.padding(&nbsp;0,&nbsp;'e'&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
299         *  Padding.padding(&nbsp;3,&nbsp;'e'&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"eee"<br>
300         *  Padding.padding(&nbsp;-2,&nbsp;'e'&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;IndexOutOfBoundsException<br>
301         *  </code>
302         *
303         *  @param  repeat  Number of times to repeat {@code padChar}; must be
304         *      0 or greater.
305         *  @param  padChar Character to repeat.
306         *  @return String with repeated {@code padChar} character, or the
307         *      empty String if {@code repeat} is 0.
308         *  @throws IndexOutOfBoundsException {@code repeat} is less than 0.
309         *
310         *  @see StringUtils#repeat(int,int)
311         */
312        private static String padding( final int repeat, final char padChar ) throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
313        {
314            if( repeat < 0 ) throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException( MSG_PadNegative.formatted( repeat ) );
315
316            final var retValue = Character.toString( padChar ).repeat( repeat ).intern();
317
318            //---* Done *------------------------------------------------------
319            return retValue;
320        }   //  padding()
321    }
322    //  enum Padding
323
324        /*-----------*\
325    ====** Constants **========================================================
326        \*-----------*/
327    /**
328     *  <p>{@summary The regular expression for an HTML or XML comment:
329     *  {@value}.}</p>
330     *  <p>This pattern is used by the
331     *  {@link #stripXMLComments(CharSequence)}
332     *  method.</p>
333     *
334     *  @since 0.0.5
335     */
336    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
337    public static final String COMMENTREMOVAL_PATTERN = "<!--.+?-->";
338
339    /**
340     *  The initial buffer size that is used by
341     *  {@code format(String, Object...)}
342     *  and
343     *  {@code format(Locale, String, Object...)}
344     *  (per thread): {@value}.
345     *
346     *  @since 0.0.5
347     *
348     *  @deprecated No longer used!
349     */
350    @Deprecated( since = "0.3.0", forRemoval = true )
351    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.3.0" )
352    public static final int FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE = 2048;
353
354    /**
355     *  The message text indicating that the given value for the abbreviation
356     *  target length is too short.
357     */
358    private static final String MSG_AbbrTooShort = "The minimum abbreviation width is %d";
359
360    /**
361     *  The message indicating that the give size for padding is negative.
362     */
363    private static final String MSG_PadNegative = "Cannot pad a negative amount: %d";
364
365    /**
366     *  The maximum size to which the padding constant(s) can expand: {@value}.
367     *
368     *  @see #repeat(CharSequence,int) repeat() for String
369     *  @see #repeat(char,int) repeat() for char
370     */
371    @SuppressWarnings( "unused" )
372    private static final int PAD_LIMIT = 8192;
373
374    /**
375     *  The regular expression for an HTML or XML tag: {@value}.<br>
376     *  <br>This pattern is used by the
377     *  {@link #stripTags(CharSequence)}
378     *  method.<br>
379     *  <br>As HTML/XML comments may contain a &quot;greater than&quot; sign
380     *  ('&gt;' or '&amp;gt;'), it is necessary to treat comments
381     *  separately.<br>
382     *  <br>Just as a reminder: several sources recommend using the following
383     *  idiom for embedded JavaScript:<pre><code>  &lt;script&gt;
384     *  &lt;!--
385     *  <i>JavaScript code </i>
386     *  --&gt;
387     *  &lt;/script&gt;</code></pre>
388     *
389     *  @since 0.0.5
390     */
391    @SuppressWarnings( "RegExpUnnecessaryNonCapturingGroup" )
392    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
393    public static final String TAGREMOVAL_PATTERN = "(?:<!--.+?-->)|(?:<[^>]+?>)";
394
395    /**
396     *  The regular expression to identify a variable in a char sequence:
397     *  {@value}.
398     *
399     *  @see #findVariables(CharSequence)
400     *  @see #isValidVariableName(CharSequence)
401     *  @see #replaceVariable(CharSequence,Map...)
402     *  @see #replaceVariable(CharSequence, Function)
403     *
404     *  @since 0.0.5
405     *  @deprecated Use
406     *      {@link Template#VARIABLE_PATTERN}
407     *      instead.
408     */
409    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
410    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
411    public static final String VARIABLE_PATTERN = Template.VARIABLE_PATTERN;
412
413    /**
414     *  The template for variables: {@value}. The argument is the name of the
415     *  variable itself; after an optional prefix character, it may not contain
416     *  other characters than the letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower
417     *  case), the digits from '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore
418     *  ('_') and dot ('.').<br>
419     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
420     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
421     *  ('&amp;').<br>
422     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
423     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
424     *  special variable.
425     *
426     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
427     *
428     *  @since 0.0.5
429     *  @deprecated Use
430     *      {@link Template#VARIABLE_TEMPLATE}
431     *      instead.
432     */
433    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
434    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
435    public static final String VARIABLE_TEMPLATE = Template.VARIABLE_TEMPLATE;
436
437        /*------------------------*\
438    ====** Static Initialisations **===========================================
439        \*------------------------*/
440    /**
441     *  The pattern that is used to identify an HTML or XML comment.
442     *
443     *  @see #stripXMLComments(CharSequence)
444     *  @see #COMMENTREMOVAL_PATTERN
445     */
446    private static final Pattern m_CommentRemovalPattern;
447
448    /**
449     *  The pattern that is used to identify an HTML or XML tag.
450     *
451     *  @see #stripTags(CharSequence)
452     *  @see #TAGREMOVAL_PATTERN
453     */
454    private static final Pattern m_TagRemovalPattern;
455
456    static
457    {
458        //---* The regex patterns *--------------------------------------------
459        try
460        {
461            m_CommentRemovalPattern = compile( COMMENTREMOVAL_PATTERN, DOTALL );
462            m_TagRemovalPattern = compile( TAGREMOVAL_PATTERN, DOTALL );
463        }
464        catch( final PatternSyntaxException e )
465        {
466            throw new ImpossibleExceptionError( "The patterns are constant values that have been tested", e );
467        }
468    }

474     *  No instance of this class is allowed.
475     */
476    private StringUtils() { throw new PrivateConstructorForStaticClassCalledError( StringUtils.class ); }

478        /*---------*\
479    ====** Methods **==========================================================
480        \*---------*/
481    /**
482     *  Abbreviates a String using ellipses (Unicode HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS,
483     *  0x2026). This will turn &quot;<i>Now is the time for all good
484     *  men</i>&quot; into &quot;<i>Now is the time for&hellip;</i>&quot;.<br>
485     *  <br>Specifically:
486     *  <ul>
487     *  <li>If {@code text} is less than {@code maxWidth} characters long,
488     *  return it unchanged.</li>
489     *  <li>Else abbreviate it to <code>(substring( text, 0, max - 1 ) +
490     *  &quot;&hellip;&quot; )</code>.</li>
491     *  <li>If {@code maxWidth} is less than 4, throw an
492     *  {@link ValidationException}.</li>
493     *  <li>In no case it will return a String of length greater than
494     *  {@code maxWidth}.</li>
495     *  </ul>
496     *  Some samples:<br>
497     *  <pre><code>
498     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( null, * )      = null
499     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "", 4 )        = ""
500     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abc", 4 ) = "abc"
501     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcd", 4 ) = "abcd;"
502     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefg", 4 ) = "abc&hellip;"
503     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefg", 7 ) = "abcdefg"
504     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefg", 8 ) = "abcdefg"
505     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefg", 3 ) = IllegalArgumentException
506     *  </code></pre>
507     *
508     *  @param  text    The String to abbreviate, can be {@code null}.
509     *  @param  maxWidth    The maximum length of result String, must be at
510     *      least 4.
511     *  @return The abbreviated String, or {@code null} if the input was
512     *      already {@code null}.
513     *  @throws ValidationException The value for {@code maxWidth} was less
514     *      than 4.
515     *
516     *  @since 0.0.5
517     */
518    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
519    public static final String abbreviate( final CharSequence text, final int maxWidth ) throws ValidationException
520    {
521        return abbreviate( text, 0, maxWidth );
522    }   //  abbreviate()
523
524    /**
525     *  Abbreviates a String using ellipses (Unicode HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS,
526     *  0x2026). This will turn &quot;<i>Now is the time for all good
527     *  men</i>&quot; into &quot;<i>&hellip;is the time
528     *  for&hellip;</i>&quot;.<br>
529     *  <br>Works like
530     *  {@link #abbreviate(CharSequence, int)},
531     *  but allows to specify a &quot;left edge&quot; offset. Note that this
532     *  left edge is not necessarily going to be the leftmost character in the
533     *  result, or the first character following the ellipses, but it will
534     *  appear somewhere in the result. An offset less than 0 will be treated
535     *  as 0, a value greater than {@code maxWidth} will be ignored.<br>
536     *  <br>In no case will it return a String of length greater than
537     *  {@code maxWidth}.<br>
538     *  <br>Some samples:<br>
539     *  <pre>
540     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( null, *, * )                = null
541     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "", 0, 4 )                  = ""
542     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", -1, 10 ) = "abcdefghi&hellip;"
543     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 0, 10 )  = "abcdefghi&hellip;"
544     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 1, 10 )  = "abcdefghi&hellip;"
545     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 4, 10 )  = "&hellip;efghijkl&hellip;"
546     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 5, 10 )  = "&hellip;fghijklm&hellip;"
547     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 6, 10 )  = "&hellip;ghijklmno"
548     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 8, 10 )  = "&hellip;ghijklmno"
549     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 10, 10 ) = "&hellip;ghijklmno"
550     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghijklmno", 12, 10 ) = "&hellip;ghijklmno"
551     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghij", 0, 3 )        = IllegalArgumentException
552     *  StringUtils.abbreviate( "abcdefghij", 5, 6 )        = IllegalArgumentException
553     *  </pre>
554     *
555     *  @param  text    The String to process, can be {@code null}.
556     *  @param  offset  The left edge of the source String; this value will not
557     *      be checked.
558     *  @param  maxWidth    The maximum length of result String, must be at
559     *      least 4.
560     *  @return The abbreviated String, or {@code null} if the input was
561     *      already {@code null}.
562     *  @throws ValidationException The value for {@code maxWidth} was less
563     *      than 4.
564     *
565     *  @since 0.0.5
566     */
567    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
568    public static final String abbreviate( final CharSequence text, final int offset, final int maxWidth ) throws ValidationException
569    {
570        final var ellipsis = Character.toString( CHAR_ELLIPSIS ).intern();
571
572        String retValue = null;
573        if( nonNull( text ) )
574        {
575            if( maxWidth < 4 ) throw new ValidationException( String.format( MSG_AbbrTooShort, 4 ) );
576
577            final var len = text.length();
578            if( len > maxWidth )
579            {
580                var effectiveOffset = min( offset, len);
581                if( (len - effectiveOffset) < (maxWidth - 1))
582                {
583                    effectiveOffset = len - (maxWidth - 1);
584                }
585                if( effectiveOffset <= 1 )
586                {
587                    retValue = text.subSequence( 0, maxWidth - 1 ) + ellipsis;
588                }
589                else
590                {
591                    if( ((effectiveOffset + maxWidth) - 1) < len )
592                    {
593                        retValue = ellipsis + abbreviate( text.subSequence( effectiveOffset, len ), maxWidth - 1 );
594                    }
595                    else
596                    {
597                        retValue = ellipsis + text.subSequence( len - (maxWidth - 1), len );
598                    }
599                }
600            }
601            else
602            {
603                retValue = text.toString();
604            }
605        }
606
607        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
608        return retValue;
609    }   //  abbreviate()
610
611    /**
612     *  Abbreviates a String using ellipses (Unicode HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS,
613     *  0x2026) in the middle of the returned text. This will turn &quot;<i>Now
614     *  is the time for all good men</i>&quot; into &quot;<i>Now is &hellip;
615     *  good men</i>&quot;<br>
616     *  <br>Works like
617     *  {@link #abbreviate(CharSequence, int)}.<br>
618     *  <br>In no case will it return a String of length greater than
619     *  {@code maxWidth}.<br>
620     *  <br>Some samples:<br>
621     *  <pre>
622     *  StringUtils.abbreviateMiddle(null, *)      = null
623     *  StringUtils.abbreviateMiddle("", 5)        = ""
624     *  StringUtils.abbreviateMiddle("abcdefgh", 5) = "ab&hellip;gh"
625     *  StringUtils.abbreviateMiddle("abcdefgh", 7) = "ab&hellip;gh"
626     *  StringUtils.abbreviateMiddle("abcdefgh", 8) = "abcdefgh"
627     *  StringUtils.abbreviateMiddle("abcdefgh", 4) = IllegalArgumentException
628     *  </pre>
629     *
630     *  @param  input   The String to check, may be {@code null}.
631     *  @param  maxWidth    The maximum length of result String, must be at
632     *      least 5.
633     *  @return The abbreviated String, or {@code null} if the input was
634     *      already {@code null}.
635     *  @throws ValidationException The value for {@code maxWidth} was less
636     *      than 5.
637     *
638     *  @since 0.0.5
639     */
640    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
641    public static final String abbreviateMiddle( final CharSequence input, final int maxWidth )
642    {
643        final var ellipsis = Character.toString( CHAR_ELLIPSIS ).intern();
644
645        String retValue = null;
646        if( nonNull( input ) )
647        {
648            if( maxWidth < 5 ) throw new ValidationException( String.format( MSG_AbbrTooShort, 5 ) );
649
650            final var len = input.length();
651            if( len > maxWidth )
652            {
653                final var suffixLength = (maxWidth - 1) / 2;
654                final var prefixLength = maxWidth - 1 - suffixLength;
655                final var suffixStart = len - suffixLength;
656                retValue = input.subSequence( 0, prefixLength ) + ellipsis + input.subSequence( suffixStart, suffixStart + suffixLength );
657            }
658            else
659            {
660                retValue = input.toString();
661            }
662        }
663
664        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
665        return retValue;
666    }   //  abbreviateMiddle()
667
668    /**
669     *  <p>{@summary Breaks a long string into chunks of the given length.}</p>
670     *  <p>This method returns an instance of
671     *  {@link Stream} that can be easily converted into an array or a
672     *  collection.</p>
673     *  <p>To array:</p>
674     *  <pre><code>breakString( &lt;<i>string</i>&gt;, &lt;<i>chunk</i>&gt; ).toArray( String []::new )</code></pre>
675     *  <p>To collection (here: a
676     *  {@link List}):</p>
677     *  <pre><code>breakString( &lt;<i>string</i>&gt;, &lt;<i>chunk</i>&gt; ).collect( Collectors.toList() )</code></pre>
678     *
679     *  @param  input   The string.
680     *  @param  chunk   The chunk size.
681     *  @return The chunks from the string; the last chunk could be shorter
682     *      than the others.
683     *
684     *  @see Stream#toArray(java.util.function.IntFunction)
685     *  @see Stream#collect(java.util.stream.Collector)
686     *  @see java.util.stream.Collectors#toList()
687     *
688     *  @since 0.0.5
689     */
690    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
691    public static final Stream<String> breakString( final CharSequence input, final int chunk )
692    {
693        if( chunk < 1 ) throw new ValidationException( "Chunk size must not be zero or a negative number: %d".formatted( chunk ) );
694
695        final Builder<String> builder = Stream.builder();
696        final var len = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).length();
697        var pos = 0;
698        while( (pos + chunk) < len )
699        {
700            builder.add( input.subSequence( pos, pos + chunk ).toString() );
701            pos += chunk;
702        }
703        if( pos < len ) builder.add( input.subSequence( pos, len ).toString() );
704
705        final var retValue = builder.build();
706
707        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
708        return retValue;
709    }   //  breakString()
710
711    /**
712     *  <p>{@summary Breaks a text into lines of the given length, but
713     *  different from
714     *  {@link #breakString(CharSequence, int)},
715     *  it will honour whitespace.}</p>
716     *  <p>This method returns an instance of
717     *  {@link Stream} that can be easily converted into an array, a String, or
718     *  a collection.</p>
719     *  <p>To array:</p>
720     *  <pre><code>breakText( &lt;<i>text</i>&gt;, &lt;<i>len</i>&gt; ).toArray( String []::new )</code></pre>
721     *  <p>To String:</p>
722     *  <pre><code>breakText( &lt;<i>text</i>&gt;, &lt;<i>len</i>&gt; ).collect( Collectors.joining() )</code></pre>
723     *  <p>To collection (here: a
724     *  {@link List}):</p>
725     *  <pre><code>breakText( &lt;<i>text</i>&gt;, &lt;<i>len</i>&gt; ).collect( Collectors.toList() )</code></pre>
726     *
727     *  @param  text    The text.
728     *  @param  lineLength  The length of a line.
729     *  @return The lines; if a word is longer than the given line length, a
730     *      line containing only that word can be longer that the given line
731     *      length.
732     *
733     *  @see Stream#toArray(java.util.function.IntFunction)
734     *  @see Stream#collect(java.util.stream.Collector)
735     *  @see java.util.stream.Collectors#joining()
736     *  @see java.util.stream.Collectors#joining(CharSequence)
737     *  @see java.util.stream.Collectors#joining(CharSequence, CharSequence, CharSequence)
738     *  @see java.util.stream.Collectors#toList()
739     *
740     *  @since 0.0.5
741     */
742    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
743    public static final Stream<String> breakText( final CharSequence text, final int lineLength )
744    {
745        if( lineLength < 1 ) throw new ValidationException( "Line length size must not be zero or a negative number: %d".formatted( lineLength ) );
746
747        final Builder<String> builder = Stream.builder();
748
749        for( final var line : splitString( requireNonNullArgument( text, "text" ), '\n' ) )
750        {
751            if( isEmptyOrBlank( line ) )
752            {
753                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
754            }
755            else
756            {
757                final var buffer = new StringBuilder();
758                final var chunks = line.split( "\\s" );
759                SplitLoop: for( final var chunk : chunks )
760                {
761                    if( chunk.isEmpty() ) continue SplitLoop;
762                    if( (buffer.length() + 1 + chunk.length()) < lineLength )
763                    {
764                        if( isNotEmpty( buffer) ) buffer.append( ' ' );
765                    }
766                    else
767                    {
768                        if( isNotEmpty( buffer ) )
769                        {
770                            builder.add( buffer.toString() );
771                            buffer.setLength( 0 );
772                        }
773                    }
774                    buffer.append( chunk );
775                }   //  SplitLoop:
776                if( isNotEmpty( buffer ) ) builder.add( buffer.toString() );
777            }
778        }
779
780        final var retValue = builder.build();
781
782        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
783        return retValue;
784    }   //  breakText()
785
786    /**
787     *  <p>{@summary <i>Capitalises</i> a String, meaning changing the first
788     *  letter to upper case as per
789     *  {@link Character#toUpperCase(char)}.} No other letters are changed.</p>
790     *  <p>A {@code null} input String returns {@code null}.</p>
791     *  <p>Samples:</p>
792     *  <pre><code>  StringUtils.capitalize( null )  == null;
793     *  StringUtils.capitalize( &quot;&quot; )    == &quot;&quot;;
794     *  StringUtils.capitalize( &quot;cat&quot; ) == &quot;Cat&quot;;
795     *  StringUtils.capitalize( &quot;cAt&quot; ) == &quot;CAt&quot;;</code></pre>
796     *  <p>Use this function to create a getter or setter name from the name of
797     *  the attribute.</p>
798     *  <p>This method does not recognise the
799     *  {@linkplain java.util.Locale#getDefault() default locale}.
800     *  This means that &quot;istanbul&quot; will become &quot;Istanbul&quot;
801     *  even for the locale {@code tr_TR} (although &quot;&#x130;stanbul&quot;
802     *  would be correct).</p>
803     *
804     *  @param input    The String to capitalise, can be {@code null}.
805     *  @return The capitalised String, or {@code null} if the argument
806     *      was already {@code null}.
807     *
808     *  @see #decapitalize(CharSequence)
809     *
810     *  @since 0.0.5
811     */
812    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
813    public static final String capitalize( final CharSequence input )
814    {
815        String retValue = null;
816        if( nonNull( input ) )
817        {
818            @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
819            final var s = input.toString();
820            if( s.isEmpty() )
821            {
822                retValue = s;
823            }
824            else
825            {
826                retValue = (toUpperCase( s.charAt( 0 ) ) + s.substring( 1 )).intern();
827            }
828        }
829
830        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
831        return retValue;
832    }   //  capitalize()
833
834    /**
835     *  Tests if the given text is not {@code null}, not empty and not
836     *  longer than the given maximum length.
837     *
838     *  @param  name    The name that should appear in the exception if one
839     *      will be thrown.
840     *  @param  text    The text to check.
841     *  @param  maxLength   The maximum length.
842     *  @return Always the contents of <code>text</code> as a String; if the
843     *      argument fails any of the tests, an
844     *      {@link IllegalArgumentException}
845     *      or an exception derived from that will be thrown.
846     *  @throws CharSequenceTooLongException    {@code text} is longer than
847     *      {@code maxLength}.
848     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException {@code text} is the empty String.
849     *  @throws NullArgumentException   Either {@code name} or {@code text} is
850     *      {@code null}.
851     *
852     *  @deprecated Replaced by
853     *      {@link #checkTextLen(String, CharSequence, int)}
854     */
855    @API( status = DEPRECATED )
856    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
857    public static final String checkText( final String name, final CharSequence text, final int maxLength ) throws CharSequenceTooLongException, EmptyArgumentException, NullArgumentException
858    {
859        return checkTextLen( name, text, maxLength );
860    }   //  checkText()

862    /**
863     *  Tests if the given text is not {@code null}, not empty and not
864     *  longer than the given maximum length. Use this to check whether a
865     *  String that is provided as an argument to a method is longer than
866     *  expected.
867     *
868     *  @param  name    The name that should appear in the exception if one
869     *      will be thrown. Usually this is the name of the argument to
870     *      validate.
871     *  @param  text    The text to check.
872     *  @param  maxLength   The maximum length.
873     *  @return Always the contents of <code>text</code> as a String; if the
874     *      argument fails any of the tests, an
875     *      {@link IllegalArgumentException}
876     *      or an exception derived from that will be thrown.
877     *  @throws CharSequenceTooLongException    {@code text} is longer than
878     *      {@code maxLength}.
879     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException Either {@code name} or {@code text} is
880     *      the empty String.
881     *  @throws NullArgumentException   Either {@code name} or {@code text} is
882     *      {@code null}.
883     *
884     *  @since 0.0.5
885     */
886    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
887    public static final String checkTextLen( final String name, final CharSequence text, final int maxLength ) throws CharSequenceTooLongException, EmptyArgumentException, NullArgumentException
888    {
889        if( requireNotEmptyArgument( text, requireNotEmptyArgument( name, "name" ) ).length() > maxLength )
890        {
891            throw new CharSequenceTooLongException( name, maxLength );
892        }
893
894        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
895        return text.toString();
896    }   //  checkTextLen()
897
898    /**
899     *  Tests if the given text is not longer than the given maximum length;
900     *  different from
901     *  {@link #checkTextLen(String, CharSequence, int)},
902     *  it may be {@code null} or empty.
903     *
904     *  @param  name    The name that should appear in the exception if one
905     *      will be thrown.
906     *  @param  text    The text to check; may be {@code null}.
907     *  @param  maxLength   The maximum length.
908     *  @return Always the contents of {@code text} as a String, {@code null}
909     *      if {@code text} was {@code null}; if the argument fails any of the
910     *      tests, an
911     *      {@link IllegalArgumentException}
912     *      or an exception derived from that will be thrown.
913     *  @throws CharSequenceTooLongException    {@code text} is longer than
914     *      {@code maxLength}.
915     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  {@code name} is empty.
916     *  @throws NullArgumentException   {@code name} is {@code null}.
917     *
918     *  @since 0.0.5
919     */
920    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
921    public static final String checkTextLenNull( final String name, final CharSequence text, final int maxLength ) throws CharSequenceTooLongException
922    {
923        requireNotEmptyArgument( name, "name" );
924
925        String retValue = null;
926        if( nonNull( text ) )
927        {
928            if( text.length() > maxLength )
929            {
930                throw new CharSequenceTooLongException( name, maxLength );
931            }
932            retValue = text.toString();
933        }
934
935        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
936        return retValue;
937    }   //  checkTextLenNull()
938
939    /**
940     *  Tests if the given text is not longer than the given maximum length;
941     *  it may be {@code null}.
942     *
943     *  @param  name    The name that should appear in the exception if one
944     *      will be thrown.
945     *  @param  text    The text to check; may be {@code null}.
946     *  @param  maxLength   The maximum length.
947     *  @return Always the contents of {@code text} as a String,
948     *      {@code null} if {@code text} was {@code null}; if the
949     *      argument fails any of the tests, an
950     *      {@link IllegalArgumentException}
951     *      or an exception derived from that will be thrown.
952     *  @throws CharSequenceTooLongException    {@code text} is longer than
953     *      {@code maxLength}.
954     *  @throws NullArgumentException   {@code name} is {@code null}.
955     *
956     *  @deprecated Replaced by
957     *      {@link #checkTextLenNull(String, CharSequence, int)}.
958     */
959    @API( status = DEPRECATED )
960    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
961    public static final String checkTextNull( final String name, final CharSequence text, final int maxLength )
962    {
963        return checkTextLenNull( name, text, maxLength );
964    }   //  checkTextNull()

966    /**
967     *  Changes the first letter of the given String tolower case as per
968     *  {@link Character#toLowerCase(char)}.
969     *  No other letters are changed. A {@code null} input String returns
970     *  {@code null}.<br>
971     *  <br>Samples:<pre><code>  StringUtils.decapitalize( null ) = null;
972     *  StringUtils.decapitalize(&quot;&quot;)     = &quot;&quot;;
973     *  StringUtils.decapitalize(&quot;Cat&quot;)  = &quot;cat&quot;;
974     *  StringUtils.decapitalize(&quot;CAT&quot;)  = &quot;cAT&quot;;</code></pre>
975     *  <br>Basically, this is the complementary method to
976     *  {@link #capitalize(CharSequence)}.
977     *  Use this method to normalise the name of bean attributes.
978     *
979     *  @param  input   The String to <i>decapitalise</i>, may be {@code null}.
980     *  @return The <i>decapitalised</i> String, {@code null} if the argument
981     *      was {@code null}.
982     *  @see #capitalize(CharSequence)
983     *
984     *  @since 0.0.5
985     */
986    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.1.0" )
987    public static final String decapitalize( final CharSequence input )
988    {
989        String retValue = null;
990
991        if( nonNull( input ) )
992        {
993            retValue = EMPTY_STRING;
994            if( isNotEmpty( input ) )
995            {
996                final var str = input.toString();
997                retValue = (toLowerCase( str.charAt( 0 ) ) + str.substring( 1 )).intern();
998            }
999        }
1000
1001        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1002        return retValue;
1003    }   //  decapitalize()
1004
1005    /**
1006     *  <p>{@summary Escapes the non-ASCII and special characters in a
1007     *  {@code String} so that the result can be used in the context of HTML.}
1008     *  Wherever possible, the method will return the respective HTML&nbsp;5
1009     *  entity; only when there is no matching entity, it will use the Unicode
1010     *  escape.</p>
1011     *  <p>So if you call the method with the argument
1012     *  &quot;<i>S&uuml;&szlig;e</i>&quot;, it will return
1013     *  &quot;<code>S&amp;uuml;&amp;szlig;e</code>&quot;.</p>
1014     *  <p>If the input will be, for example, a Chinese text like this:
1015     *  &quot;<i>çä½</i>&quot; (means "Ball"), you may get back something like
1016     *  this: &quot;<code>&amp;#x7403;&amp;#x4F53;</code>&quot;, as there are
1017     *  no entities defined for (any) Chinese letters.</p>
1018     *  <p>The method supports all known HTML&nbsp;5.0 entities, including
1019     *  funky accents. But it will not escape several commonly used characters
1020     *  like the full stop ('.'), the comma (','), the colon (':'), or the
1021     *  semicolon (';'), although they will be handled properly by
1022     *  {@link #unescapeHTML(CharSequence)}.</p>
1023     *  <p>Note that the commonly used apostrophe escape character
1024     *  (&amp;apos;) that was not a legal entity for HTML before HTML&nbsp;5 is
1025     *  now supported.</p>
1026     *
1027     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to escape, may be {@code null}.
1028     *  @return A new escaped {@code String}, or {@code null} if the
1029     *      argument was already {@code null}.
1030     *
1031     *  @see #unescapeHTML(CharSequence)
1032     *  @see <a href="http://hotwired.lycos.com/webmonkey/reference/special_characters/">ISO Entities</a>
1033     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html32#latin1">HTML 3.2 Character Entities for ISO Latin-1</a>
1034     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/entities.html">HTML 4.0 Character entity references</a>
1035     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/charset.html#h-5.3">HTML 4.01 Character References</a>
1036     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/charset.html#code-position">HTML 4.01 Code positions</a>
1037     *
1038     *  @since 0.0.5
1039     */
1040    /*
1041     *  For some unknown reasons, JavaDoc will not accept the entities &#x7403;
1042     *  and &#x4F53; (for 'ç' and 'ä½'), therefore it was required to add the
1043     *  Chinese characters directly into the comment above.
1044     */
1045    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1046    public static final String escapeHTML( final CharSequence input )
1047    {
1048        final var retValue = nonNull( input ) ? HTML50.escape( input ) : null;
1049
1050        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1051        return retValue;
1052    }   //  escapeHTML()
1053
1054    /**
1055     *  Escapes the characters in a {@code String} using HTML entities and
1056     *  writes them to an
1057     *  {@link Appendable}.
1058     *  For details, refer to
1059     *  {@link #escapeHTML(CharSequence)}.
1060     *
1061     *  @param  appendable  The appendable object receiving the escaped string.
1062     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to escape, may be {@code null}.
1063     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
1064     *  @throws IOException when {@code Appendable} passed throws the exception
1065     *      from calls to the
1066     *      {@link Appendable#append(char)}
1067     *      method.
1068     *
1069     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
1070     *  @see #unescapeHTML(CharSequence)
1071     *  @see <a href="http://hotwired.lycos.com/webmonkey/reference/special_characters/">ISO Entities</a>
1072     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html32#latin1">HTML 3.2 Character Entities for ISO Latin-1</a>
1073     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/entities.html">HTML 4.0 Character entity references</a>
1074     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/charset.html#h-5.3">HTML 4.01 Character References</a>
1075     *  @see <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/charset.html#code-position">HTML 4.01 Code positions</a>
1076     *
1077     *  @since 0.0.5
1078     */
1079    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1080    public static final void escapeHTML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence input ) throws IOException
1081    {
1082        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
1083
1084        if( nonNull( input ) ) HTML50.escape( appendable, input );
1085    }   //  escapeHTML()
1086
1087    /**
1088     *  Formats the given {@code String} for the output into JSONText. This
1089     *  means that the input sequence will be surrounded by double quotes, and
1090     *  backslash sequences are put into all the right places.<br>
1091     *  <br>&lt; and &gt; will be inserted as their Unicode values, allowing
1092     *  JSON text to be delivered in HTML.<br>
1093     *  <br>In JSON text, a string cannot contain a control character or an
1094     *  unescaped quote or backslash, so these are translated to Unicode
1095     *  escapes also.
1096     *
1097     *  @param  input   The string to escape to the JSON format; it may be
1098     *      empty, but not {@code null}.
1099     *  @return A string correctly formatted for insertion in a JSON text.
1100     *
1101     *  @since 0.0.5
1102     */
1103    @SuppressWarnings( "OverlyComplexMethod" )
1104    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1105    public static final String escapeJSON( final CharSequence input )
1106    {
1107        var retValue = "\"\""; // The JSON empty string.
1108        final var len = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).length();
1109        if( len > 0 )
1110        {
1111            final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len * 2 ).append( '"' );
1112            @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
1113            char c;
1114            for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
1115            {
1116                c = input.charAt( i );
1117                switch( c )
1118                {
1119                    case '\\', '"', '<', '>', '&' -> buffer.append( escapeCharacter( c ) );
1120
1121                    case '\b' -> buffer.append( "\\b" );
1122
1123                    case '\t' -> buffer.append( "\\t" );
1124
1125                    case '\n'-> buffer.append( "\\n" );
1126
1127                    case '\f' -> buffer.append( "\\f" );
1128
1129                    case '\r' -> buffer.append( "\\r" );
1130
1131                    default ->
1132                    {
1133                        //noinspection OverlyComplexBooleanExpression,CharacterComparison,UnnecessaryUnicodeEscape
1134                        if( (c < ' ')
1135                            || ((c >= '\u0080') && (c < '\u00a0'))
1136                            || ((c >= '\u2000') && (c < '\u2100')) )
1137                        {
1138                            buffer.append( escapeCharacter( c ) );
1139                        }
1140                        else
1141                        {
1142                            buffer.append( c );
1143                        }
1144                    }
1145                }
1146            }
1147            buffer.append( '"' );
1148            retValue = buffer.toString();
1149        }
1150
1151        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1152        return retValue;
1153    }   //  escapeJSON()
1154
1155    /**
1156     *  Escapes the given character using Regex escapes and writes them to a
1157     *  {@link Appendable}.
1158     *
1159     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the escaped string.
1160     *  @param  c   The character to escape.
1161     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
1162     *  @throws IOException when {@code Appendable} passed throws the exception
1163     *      from calls to the
1164     *      {@link Appendable#append(CharSequence)}
1165     *      method.
1166     *
1167     *  @since 0.0.5
1168     */
1169    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
1170    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1171    public static final void escapeRegex( final Appendable appendable, final char c ) throws IOException
1172    {
1173        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
1174
1175        TestSwitch: switch( c )
1176        {
1177            case '\\' -> appendable.append( "\\" );
1178            case '[', ']', '{', '}', '(', ')', '^', '$', '&', '*', '.', '+', '|', '?' -> appendable.append( "\\" ).append( c );
1179            case '\t' -> appendable.append( "\\t" );
1180            case '\n' -> appendable.append( "\\n" );
1181            case '\r' -> appendable.append( "\\r" );
1182            case '\f' -> appendable.append( "\\f" );
1183            case '\u0007' -> appendable.append( "\\a" );
1184            case '\u001B' -> appendable.append( "\\e" ); // ESC
1185            default -> appendable.append( c );
1186        }   //  TestSwitch:
1187    }   //  escapeRegex()
1188
1189    /**
1190     *  Escapes the given character using Regex escapes.
1191     *
1192     *  @param  c   The character to escape.
1193     *  @return A {@code String} with the escaped character.
1194     *
1195     *  @since 0.0.5
1196     */
1197    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1198    public static final String escapeRegex( final char c )
1199    {
1200        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
1201        try
1202        {
1203            escapeRegex( retValue, c );
1204        }
1205        catch( final IOException e )
1206        {
1207            /*
1208             * We append to a StringBuilder, and StringBuilder.append() does
1209             * not define an IOException.
1210             */
1211            throw new ImpossibleExceptionError( e );
1212        }
1213
1214        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1215        return retValue.toString();
1216    }   //  escapeRegex()
1217
1218    /**
1219     *  Escapes the characters in a {@code String} using Regex escapes.
1220     *
1221     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to escape, may be {@code null}.
1222     *  @return A new escaped {@code String}, or {@code null} if the argument
1223     *      was already {@code null}.
1224     *
1225     *  @since 0.0.5
1226     */
1227    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1228    public static final String escapeRegex( final CharSequence input )
1229    {
1230        String retValue = null;
1231        if( nonNull( input ) )
1232        {
1233            final var len = input.length();
1234            if( len > 0 )
1235            {
1236                final var buffer = new StringBuilder( (len * 12) / 10 );
1237                try
1238                {
1239                    escapeRegex( buffer, input );
1240                }
1241                catch( final IOException e )
1242                {
1243                    /*
1244                     * We append to a StringBuilder, and StringBuilder.append() does
1245                     * not define an IOException.
1246                     */
1247                    throw new ImpossibleExceptionError( e );
1248                }
1249                retValue = buffer.toString();
1250            }
1251            else
1252            {
1253                retValue = EMPTY_STRING;
1254            }
1255        }
1256
1257        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1258        return retValue;
1259    }   //  escapeRegex()
1260
1261    /**
1262     *  Escapes the characters in a {@code String} using Regex escapes and
1263     *  writes them to a
1264     *  {@link Appendable}.
1265     *
1266     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the escaped string.
1267     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to escape. If {@code null} or the empty
1268     *      String, nothing will be put to the appendable.
1269     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
1270     *  @throws IOException when {@code Appendable} passed throws the exception
1271     *      from calls to the
1272     *      {@link Appendable#append(CharSequence)}
1273     *      method.
1274     *
1275     *  @since 0.0.5
1276     */
1277    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1278    public static final void escapeRegex( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence input ) throws IOException
1279    {
1280        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
1281
1282        if( isNotEmpty( input ) )
1283        {
1284            ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < input.length(); ++i )
1285            {
1286                escapeRegex( appendable, input.charAt( i ) );
1287            }   //  ScanLoop:
1288        }
1289    }   //  escapeRegex()
1290
1291    /**
1292     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given character. This will
1293     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
1294     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.<br>
1295     *  <br>This method should be used only for characters that are not
1296     *  surrogates; for general use, the implementation that takes a code point
1297     *  is preferred.
1298     *
1299     *  @param  c   The character.
1300     *  @return The escape sequence.
1301     *
1302     *  @see #escapeUnicode(int)
1303     *
1304     *  @since 0.0.5
1305     *  @deprecated Use
1306     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(char)}
1307     *      instead.
1308     */
1309    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
1310    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
1311    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
1312    public static final String escapeUnicode( final char c ) { return escapeCharacter( c ); }
1313
1314    /**
1315     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given code point. This will
1316     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
1317     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.<br>
1318     *  <br>This method takes only a single code point; to translate a whole
1319     *  String, this code sequence can be used:<pre><code>  &hellip;
1320     *  String result = input.codePoints()
1321     *      .mapToObj( codePoint -&gt; escapeUnicode( codePoint ) )
1322     *      .collect( Collectors.joining() );
1323     *  &hellip;</code></pre>
1324     *  This will escape <i>all</i> characters in the String. If only a subset
1325     *  needs to be escaped, the mapping function in
1326     *  {@link java.util.stream.IntStream#mapToObj(java.util.function.IntFunction) mapToObj()}
1327     *  can be adjusted accordingly. Something like that is implemented with
1328     *  the method
1329     *  {@link #toUnicode(CharSequence)}.
1330     *
1331     *  @param  codePoint   The character.
1332     *  @return The escape sequence.
1333     *
1334     *  @see String#codePoints()
1335     *  @see java.util.stream.IntStream#mapToObj(java.util.function.IntFunction)
1336     *  @see java.util.stream.Stream#collect(java.util.stream.Collector)
1337     *  @see java.util.stream.Collectors#joining()
1338     *
1339     *  @since 0.0.5
1340     *  @deprecated Use
1341     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(int)}
1342     *      instead.
1343     */
1344    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
1345    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
1346    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
1347    public static final String escapeUnicode( final int codePoint ) { return escapeCharacter( codePoint ); }
1348
1349    /**
1350     *  <p>{@summary Escapes the characters in a {@code String} using XML
1351     *  entities.}</p>
1352     *  <p>For example:</p>
1353     *  <p>{@code "bread" & "butter"}</p>
1354     *  <p>becomes:</p>
1355     *  <p><code>&amp;quot;bread&amp;quot; &amp;amp;
1356     *  &amp;quot;butter&amp;quot;</code>.</p>
1357     *
1358     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to escape, may be null.
1359     *  @return A new escaped {@code String}, or {@code null} if the
1360     *      argument was already {@code null}.
1361     *
1362     *  @see #unescapeXML(CharSequence)
1363     */
1364    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1365    public static final String escapeXML( final CharSequence input )
1366    {
1367        final var retValue = nonNull( input ) ? XML.escape( input ) : null;
1368
1369        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1370        return retValue;
1371    }   //  escapeXML()

1373    /**
1374     *  <p>{@summary Escapes the characters in a {@code String} using XML

1388     *      {@link Appendable#append(char)}
1389     *      method.

1404    /**
1405     *  Collects all the variables of the form
1406     *  <code>${<i>&lt;name&gt;</i>}</code> in the given String.<br>
1407     *  <br>If there are not any variables in the given String, an empty
1408     *  {@link Collection}
1409     *  will be returned.<br>
1410     *  <br>A valid variable name may not contain any other characters than the
1411     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
1412     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
1413     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
1414     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
1415     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
1416     *  ('&amp;').<br>
1417     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
1418     *  special variable.
1419     *
1420     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
1421     *  @return A {@code Collection} with the variable (names).
1422     *
1423     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
1424     *
1425     *  @since 0.0.5
1426     *  @deprecated Use
1427     *      {@link Template#findVariables(CharSequence)}
1428     *      instead.
1429     */
1430    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
1431    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
1432    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
1433    public static final Collection<String> findVariables( final CharSequence text )
1434    {
1435        return Template.findVariables( text );
1436    }   //  findVariables()
1437
1438    /**
1439     *  Returns a formatted String using the specified format String and
1440     *  arguments.<br>
1441     *  <br>The implementation uses internally the
1442     *  {@link Locale}
1443     *  that is returned by
1444     *  {@link java.util.Locale#getDefault() Locale.getDefault()}.<br>
1445     *  <br>This method is meant as a replacement for the method
1446     *  {@link java.lang.String#format(String, Object...)};
1447     *  that implementation always uses a new instance of
1448     *  {@link Formatter}
1449     *  for each invocation. The implementation here uses a cached instance
1450     *  instead, and as {@code Formatter} is not inherently thread-safe, this
1451     *  cached instance is created and stored per thread, therefore no
1452     *  synchronisation is needed.<br>
1453     *  <br>This implementation is about as twice as fast as
1454     *  {@code java.lang.String.format()}.
1455     *
1456     *  @param  format  A format String with the syntax as described for the
1457     *      {@link Formatter}
1458     *      class.
1459     *  @param  args    The arguments referenced by the format specifiers in
1460     *      the {@code format} String. If there are more arguments than format
1461     *      specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of
1462     *      arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of
1463     *      arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as
1464     *      defined by <cite>The Java&trade; Virtual Machine
1465     *      Specification</cite>. The behaviour on a {@code null} argument
1466     *      depends on the conversion.
1467     *  @throws IllegalFormatException A format string contains an illegal
1468     *      syntax, a format specifier that is incompatible with the given
1469     *      arguments, insufficient arguments given the format string, or other
1470     *      illegal conditions occurred. For specification of all possible
1471     *      formatting errors, see the &quot;Details&quot; section of the
1472     *      {@code Formatter} class specification.
1473     *  @return A formatted String.
1474     *
1475     *  @see  java.util.Formatter
1476     *
1477     *  @since 0.0.5
1478     *  @deprecated
1479     *      {@link org.tquadrat.foundation.lang.internal.SharedFormatter}
1480     *      got obsolete. See there.
1481     */
1482    @SuppressWarnings( "removal" )
1483    @Deprecated( since = "0.3.0", forRemoval = true )
1484    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.3.0" )
1485    public static final String format( final String format, final Object... args ) throws IllegalFormatException
1486    {
1487        return String.format( format, args );
1488    }   //  format()
1489
1490    /**
1491     *  Returns a formatted String using the specified
1492     *  {@link Locale},
1493     *  format String, and arguments.<br>
1494     *  <br>This method is meant as a replacement for the method
1495     *  {@link java.lang.String#format(String, Object...)};
1496     *  that implementation always uses a new instance of
1497     *  {@link Formatter}
1498     *  for each invocation. The implementation here uses a cached instance
1499     *  instead, and as {@code Formatter} is not inherently thread-safe, this
1500     *  cached instance is created and stored per thread, therefore no
1501     *  synchronisation is needed.<br>
1502     *  <br>The performance gain for this implementation is not that impressive
1503     *  when compared with that of
1504     *  {@link #format(String, Object...)},
1505     *  but still in the 10% range.
1506     *  {@code java.lang.String.format()}.
1507     *
1508     *  @param  locale  The
1509     *      {@link Locale}
1510     *      that will be applied during formatting. If {@code locale} is
1511     *      {@code null} then no localisation is applied.
1512     *  @param  format  A format String with the syntax as described for the
1513     *      {@link Formatter}
1514     *      class.
1515     *  @param  args    The arguments referenced by the format specifiers in
1516     *      the {@code format} String. If there are more arguments than format
1517     *      specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of
1518     *      arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of
1519     *      arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as
1520     *      defined by <cite>The Java&trade; Virtual Machine
1521     *      Specification</cite>. The behaviour on a {@code null} argument
1522     *      depends on the conversion.
1523     *  @throws IllegalFormatException A format string contains an illegal
1524     *      syntax, a format specifier that is incompatible with the given
1525     *      arguments, insufficient arguments given the format string, or other
1526     *      illegal conditions occurred. For specification of all possible
1527     *      formatting errors, see the &quot;Details&quot; section of the
1528     *      {@code Formatter} class specification.
1529     *  @return A formatted String.
1530     *
1531     *  @see  java.util.Formatter
1532     *
1533     *  @since 0.0.5
1534     *  @deprecated
1535     *      {@link org.tquadrat.foundation.lang.internal.SharedFormatter}
1536     *      got obsolete. See there.
1537     */
1538    @SuppressWarnings( "removal" )
1539    @Deprecated( since = "0.3.0", forRemoval = true )
1540    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.3.0" )
1541    public static final String format( final Locale locale, final String format, final Object... args ) throws IllegalFormatException
1542    {
1543        return String.format( locale, format, args );
1544    }   //  format()
1545

1708    /**

1724    public static final String joinString( final Collection<? extends CharSequence> input, final CharSequence separator )
1725    {
1726        final var retValue = join( requireNonNullArgument( separator, "separator" ), requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ) );
1727
1728        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1729        return retValue;
1730    }   //  joinString()

1732    /**
1733     *  Combines the given
1734     *  {@link Stream}
1735     *  of Strings to a single string, with the given separator.
1736     *
1737     *  @param  input   The input sequence.
1738     *  @param  separator   The separator; may be empty, but not {@code null}.
1739     *  @return The combined String. If the input sequence stream is empty,
1740     *      the empty String will be returned.
1741     *
1742     *  @deprecated This method is obsolete; the same effect can be achieved
1743     *      easily by calling
1744     *      {@link Stream#collect(java.util.stream.Collector)}
1745     *      on the stream, with the collector
1746     *      {@link java.util.stream.Collectors#joining(CharSequence) joining()}
1747     *      as its argument.
1748     */
1749    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.4" )
1750    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true, since = "Java 8" )
1751    public static final String joinString( final Stream<? extends CharSequence> input, final CharSequence separator )
1752    {
1753        final var retValue = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).collect( joining( separator ) );
1754
1755        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1756        return retValue;
1757    }   //  joinString()

1805    /**
1806     *  Determines the maximum length over all strings provided in the given
1807     *  collection.<br>
1808     *  <br>For an array, this method can be called like this:<pre><code>  String [] a = {"1", "2", "3"};
1809     *  maxContentLength( Arrays.asList( a ) );</code></pre>
1810     *
1811     *  @param  list    The strings.
1812     *  @return The length of the longest string in the list; -1 if all values
1813     *      in the list are {@code null}.
1814     *
1815     *  @deprecated Use
1816     *      {@link #maxContentLength(CharSequence[])},
1817     *      {@link #maxContentLength(Collection)},
1818     *      or
1819     *      {@link #maxContentLength(Stream)}
1820     *      instead.
1821     */
1822    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
1823    @API( status = DEPRECATED )
1824    public static final int maxContentLength( final Iterable<? extends CharSequence> list )
1825    {
1826        var retValue = Integer.MIN_VALUE;
1827        int len;
1828        for( final var cs : requireNonNullArgument( list, "list" ) )
1829        {
1830            len = nonNull( cs ) ? cs.length() : -1;
1831            if( len > retValue )
1832            {
1833                retValue = len;
1834            }
1835        }
1836
1837        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1838        return retValue;
1839    }   //  maxContentLength()
1840
1841    /**
1842     *  Determines the maximum length over all Strings provided in the given
1843     *  {@link Stream}.
1844     *
1845     *  @param  stream  The strings.
1846     *  @return The length of the longest string in the list; -1 if all values
1847     *      in the given {@code stream} are {@code null}, and
1848     *      {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}
1849     *      if the given {@code stream} is empty.
1850     *
1851     *  @since 0.0.5
1852     */
1853    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1854    public static final int maxContentLength( final Stream<? extends CharSequence> stream )
1855    {
1856        final var retValue = requireNonNullArgument( stream, "stream" )
1857            .mapToInt( string -> nonNull( string ) ? string.length() : -1 )
1858            .max()
1859            .orElse( Integer.MIN_VALUE );
1860
1861        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1862        return retValue;
1863    }   //  maxContentLength()
1864
1865    /**
1866     *  Determines the maximum length over all strings provided in the given
1867     *  {@link Collection}.
1868     *
1869     *  @param  list    The strings.
1870     *  @return The length of the longest string in the list; -1 if all values
1871     *      in the given {@code list} are {@code null}, and
1872     *      {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}
1873     *      if the given {@code list} is empty.
1874     *
1875     *  @since 0.0.5
1876     */
1877    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1878    public static final int maxContentLength( final Collection<? extends CharSequence> list )
1879    {
1880        final var retValue = maxContentLength( requireNonNullArgument( list, "list" ).stream() );
1881
1882        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1883        return retValue;
1884    }   //  maxContentLength()
1885
1886    /**
1887     *  Determines the maximum length over all strings provided in the given
1888     *  array.
1889     *
1890     *  @param  a   The strings.
1891     *  @return The length of the longest string in the list; -1 if all values
1892     *      in the array are {@code null}, and
1893     *      {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}
1894     *      if the given array has zero length.
1895     *
1896     *  @since 0.0.5
1897     */
1898    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1899    public static final int maxContentLength( final CharSequence... a )
1900    {
1901        final var retValue = maxContentLength( Arrays.stream( requireNonNullArgument( a, "a" ) ) );
1902
1903        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1904        return retValue;
1905    }   //  maxContentLength()

1907    /**
1908     *  <p>{@summary Normalizes the given String to a pure ASCII String.} This
1909     *  replaces 'Ã' by 'ss' and replaces all diacritical characters by their
1910     *  base form (that mean that 'Ã¼' gets 'u' and so on). For the normalizing
1911     *  of a search criteria, this should be sufficient, although it may cause
1912     *  issues for non-latin scripts, as for these the input can be mapped to
1913     *  the empty String.
1914     *
1915     *  @note   The scandinavian letters 'Ã¸' and 'Ã' are not diacritical
1916     *      letters, nevertheless they will be replaced.
1917     *
1918     *  @param  input   The input string.
1919     *  @return The normalised String, only containing ASCII characters; it
1920     *      could be empty.
1921     *
1922     *  TODO Check the implementation and the results!! 2022-12-10
1923     */
1924    public static final String normalizeToASCII( final CharSequence input )
1925    {
1926        final var str = requireNonNullArgument( input, "s" ).toString()
1927            .replace( "Ã", "ss" )
1928            .replace( 'Ã¸', 'o' )
1929            .replace( 'Ã', 'O' );
1930        final var retValue = normalize( str, NFD )
1931            .replaceAll( "[^\\p{ASCII}]", EMPTY_STRING );
1932
1933        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1934        return retValue;
1935    }   //  normalizeToASCII()
1936
1937    /**
1938     *  Brings the given string to the given length and uses the provided
1939     *  padding character to fill up the string.
1940     *
1941     *  @param  input   The string to format.
1942     *  @param  length  The desired length; if 0 or less, the given string is
1943     *      returned, regardless of {@code clip}.
1944     *  @param  c   The pad character.
1945     *  @param  mode    The
1946     *      {@linkplain StringUtils.Padding pad mode}.
1947     *  @param  clip    {@code true} if the input string should be cut in case
1948     *      it is longer than {@code length}, {@code false} if it has to be
1949     *      returned unchanged .
1950     *  @return The re-formatted string.
1951     *
1952     *  @since 0.0.5
1953     */
1954    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1955    public static final String pad( final CharSequence input, final int length, final char c, final Padding mode, final boolean clip )
1956    {
1957        return pad( input, length, c, mode, clip ? CLIPPING_CUT : CLIPPING_NONE );
1958    }   //  pad()
1959
1960    /**
1961     *  Brings the given string to the given length and uses the provided
1962     *  padding character to fill up the string.
1963     *
1964     *  @param  input   The string to format.
1965     *  @param  length  The desired length; if 0 or less, the given string is
1966     *      returned, regardless of {@code clip}.
1967     *  @param  c   The pad character.
1968     *  @param  mode    The
1969     *      {@linkplain StringUtils.Padding pad mode}.
1970     *  @param  clip    The
1971     *      {@linkplain StringUtils.Clipping clipping mode}.
1972     *  @return The re-formatted string.
1973     *
1974     *  @since 0.0.5
1975     */
1976    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
1977    public static final String pad( final CharSequence input, final int length, final char c, final Padding mode, final Clipping clip )
1978    {
1979        //noinspection OverlyComplexBooleanExpression
1980        if( ((requireNonNullArgument( clip, "clip" ) == CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE) && (length < 4)) || ((clip == CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE_MIDDLE) && (length < 5)) )
1981        {
1982            throw new ValidationException( "Length %d is too short for clipping mode %s".formatted( length, clip.toString() ) );
1983        }
1984        requireNonNullArgument( mode, "mode" );
1985
1986        final String retValue;
1987        final var currentLength = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).length();
1988
1989        if( (length > 0) && (length != currentLength) )
1990        {
1991            if( currentLength > length )
1992            {
1993                retValue = clip.clip( input, length );
1994            }
1995            else
1996            {
1997                final var padSize = length - currentLength;
1998                retValue = mode.pad( input, padSize, c );
1999            }
2000        }
2001        else
2002        {
2003            retValue = input.toString();
2004        }
2005
2006        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2007        return retValue;
2008    }   //  pad()
2009
2010    /**
2011     *  <p>{@summary Fills up the given string to the given length by adding
2012     *  blanks on both sides; will abbreviate the string if it is longer than
2013     *  the given length.} The minimum length is 5.</p>
2014     *  <p>This is a shortcut to a call to
2015     *  {@link #pad(CharSequence,int,char,Padding,Clipping) pad( input, length, ' ', PADDING_CENTER, CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE_MIDDLE ) }.</p>
2016     *

2018     *  @param  length  The desired length; minimum value is 5.
2019     *  @return The re-formatted string.

2021     *  @see Padding#PADDING_CENTER
2022     *  @see Clipping#CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE_MIDDLE
2023     *
2024     *  @since 0.0.5
2025     */
2026    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2027    public static final String padCenter( final CharSequence input, final int length ) { return pad( input, length, ' ', PADDING_CENTER, CLIPPING_ABBREVIATE_MIDDLE ); }

2067    /**
2068     *  <p>{@summary Surrounds the given String with double-quotes
2069     *  (&quot;, &amp;#34;).}</p>
2070     *  <p>When the double-quote is needed in a String constant, it has to be
2071     *  escaped with a backslash:</p>
2072     *  <pre><code>&quot;\&quot;â¦\&quot;&quot;</code></pre>
2073     *  <p>Sometimes, this is just ugly, and there this method comes into
2074     *  play.</p>
2075     *
2076     *  @param  input   The String to surround; can be {@code null}.
2077     *  @return The quoted String; will be {@code null} if the argument was
2078     *      {@code null} already.
2079     */
2080    public static final String quote( final CharSequence input )
2081    {
2082        final var retValue = isNull( input ) ? null : String.format( "\"%s\"", input );
2083
2084        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2085        return retValue;
2086    }   //  quote()

2088    /**
2089     *  <p>{@summary This method replaces all diacritical characters in the
2090     *  input String by their base form.} That means that 'Ã¼' gets 'u', `Ã'
2091     *  gets 'E' and so on).</p>
2092     *  <p>This differs from
2093     *  {@link #normalizeToASCII(CharSequence)}
2094     *  as this method still allows non-ASCII characters in the output.</p>
2095     *
2096     *  @note   The scandinavian letters 'Ã¸' and 'Ã' are not diacritical
2097     *      letters, meaning they will not be replaced.
2098     *
2099     *  @param  input   The input string.
2100     *  @return The normalised String, not containing any diacritical
2101     *      characters.
2102     *
2103     *  TODO Check the implementation and the results!! 2022-12-10
2104     */
2105    public static final String removeDiacriticalMarks( final CharSequence input )
2106    {
2107        final var retValue = normalize( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ), NFD )
2108            .replaceAll("\\p{InCombiningDiacriticalMarks}+", EMPTY_STRING );
2109
2110        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2111        return retValue;
2112    }   //  removeDiacriticalMarks()
