2114    /**
2115     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat} to form a new String. The table
2116     *  below shows the various  result for some argument combinations.<br>
2117     *  <br><code>
2118     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2119     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2120     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2121     *  </code>
2122     *
2123     *  @param  c   The character to repeat.
2124     *  @param  count   The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
2125     *      value will be treated as zero.
2126     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
2127     *      {@code count} times, or the empty String if {@code count} was 0
2128     *      or negative.
2129     *
2130     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2131     *
2132     *  @since 0.0.5
2133     */
2134    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2135    public static final String repeat( final char c, final int count )
2136    {
2137        final var retValue = ( count > 0 ? Character.toString( c ).repeat( count ) : EMPTY_STRING).intern();
2138
2139        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2140        return retValue;
2141    }   //  repeat()
2142
2143    /**
2144     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat}, identified by its code point, to
2145     *  form a new String. The
2146     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
2147     *  combinations.<br>
2148     *  <br><code>
2149     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2150     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2151     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2152     *  </code>
2153     *
2154     *  @param  codePoint   The character to repeat.
2155     *  @param  count   The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
2156     *      value will be treated as zero.
2157     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
2158     *      {@code count} times, or the empty String if {@code count} was 0
2159     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the code point is invalid.
2160     *
2161     *  @see Character#isValidCodePoint(int)
2162     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2163     *
2164     *  @since 0.0.5
2165     */
2166    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2167    public static final String repeat( final int codePoint, final int count )
2168    {
2169        final var retValue = (count > 0)
2170            ? isValidCodePoint( codePoint )
2171                ? Character.toString( codePoint ).repeat( count ).intern()
2172                : null
2173            : EMPTY_STRING;
2174
2175        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2176        return retValue;
2177    }   //  repeat()
2178
2179    /**
2180     *  Repeats the given String {@code repeat} times to form a new String. The
2181     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
2182     *  combinations.<br>
2183     *  <br><code>
2184     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;null,&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;null<br>
2185     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2186     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2187     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2188     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"ab",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"abab"<br>
2189     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2190     *  </code>
2191     *
2192     *  @param  input The String to repeat, may be {@code null}.
2193     *  @param  count   The number of times to repeat {@code str}; a negative
2194     *      value will be treated as zero.
2195     *  @return A new String consisting of the original String repeated,
2196     *      {@code count} times, the empty String if {@code count} was 0
2197     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the input String was
2198     *      {@code null}, too.
2199     *
2200     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2201     *
2202     *  @since 0.0.5
2203     */
2204    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2205    public static final String repeat( final CharSequence input, final int count )
2206    {
2207        final var retValue =
2208            nonNull( input )
2209                ? (count > 0) && !input.isEmpty()
2210                    ? input.toString().repeat( count )
2211                    : EMPTY_STRING
2212                : null;
2213
2214        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2215        return retValue;
2216    }   //  repeat()
2217
2218    /**
2219     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2220     *  in the given String with values from the given maps. The method will
2221     *  try the maps in the given sequence.<br>
2222     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2223     *  replaced at all.<br>
2224     *  <br>If a value from one of the maps contains a variable itself, this
2225     *  will not be replaced.<br>
2226     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2227     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2228     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2229     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2230     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2231     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2232     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2233     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2234     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2235     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2236     *  special variable.
2237     *
2238     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2239     *  @param  sources The maps with the replacement values.
2240     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2241     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2242     *
2243     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2244     *
2245     *  @since 0.0.5
2246     *  @deprecated Use
2247     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Map[])}
2248     *      instead.
2249     */
2250    @SafeVarargs
2251    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2252    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2253    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Map<String,? extends Object>... sources )
2254    {
2255        return Template.replaceVariable( text, sources );
2256    }   //  replaceVariable()
2257
2258    /**
2259     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2260     *  in the given String with values returned by the given retriever
2261     *  function for the variable name.<br>
2262     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2263     *  replaced at all.<br>
2264     *  <br>If the retriever function returns a value that contains a variable
2265     *  itself, this will not be replaced.<br>
2266     *  <br>The retriever function will be called only once for each variable
2267     *  name; if the text contains the same variable multiple times, it will
2268     *  always be replaced with the same value.<br>
2269     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2270     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2271     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2272     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2273     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2274     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2275     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2276     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2277     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2278     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2279     *  special variable.
2280     *
2281     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2282     *  @param  retriever   The function that will retrieve the replacement
2283     *      values for the given variable names.
2284     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2285     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2286     *
2287     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2288     *
2289     *  @since 0.0.5
2290     *  @deprecated Use
2291     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Function)}
2292     *      instead.
2293     */
2294    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2295    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2296    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Function<? super String, Optional<String>> retriever )
2297    {
2298        return Template.replaceVariable( text, retriever );
2299    }   //  replaceVariable()

2301    /**
2302     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character and
2303     *  returns an array of all parts.} In case a separator character is
2304     *  immediately followed by another separator character, an empty String
2305     *  will be placed to the array.</p>
2306     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2307     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2308     *  start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty String if the
2309     *  last character is a separator.</p>
2310     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2311     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
2312     *
2313     *  @param  input  The String to split.
2314     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2315     *  @return The parts of the String.
2316     *
2317     *  @since 0.0.5
2318     */
2319    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2320    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence input, final char separator )
2321    {
2322        return splitString( input, (int) separator );
2323    }   //  splitString()

2325    /**
2326     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character,
2327     *  identified by its Unicode code point, and returns an array of all
2328     *  parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2329     *  another separator character, an empty String will be placed to the
2330     *  array.</p>
2331     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2332     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2333     *  start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty String if the
2334     *  last character is a separator.</p>
2335     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2336     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
2337     *
2338     *  @param  input  The String to split.
2339     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2340     *  @return The parts of the String.
2341     *
2342     *  @since 0.0.5
2343     */
2344    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2345    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence input, final int separator )
2346    {
2347        final var retValue = stream( input, separator ).toArray( String []::new );
2348
2349        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2350        return retValue;
2351    }   //  splitString()

2354     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator sequence and
2355     *  returns an array of all parts.} In case a separator sequence is
2356     *  immediately followed by another separator sequence, an empty String
2357     *  will be placed to the array.</p>
2358     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2359     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned

2370     */
2371    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2372    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence input, final CharSequence separator )
2373    {
2374        final var retValue = stream( input, separator).toArray( String []::new );
2375
2376        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2377        return retValue;

2380    /**
2381     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character and
2382     *  returns an instance of
2383     *  {@link Stream}
2384     *  providing all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately
2385     *  followed by another separator character, an empty String will be put to
2386     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
2387     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2388     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned
2389     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end with an
2390     *  empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
2391     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2392     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2393     *  empty.</p>
2394     *
2395     *  @param  input  The String to split.
2396     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2397     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2398     *
2399     *  @since 0.0.7
2400     */
2401    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2402    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final char separator )
2403    {
2404        return stream( input, (int) separator );
2405    }   //  stream()
2406
2407    /**
2408     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2409     *  Unicode code point, and returns a
2410     *  {@link Stream}
2411     *  of all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2412     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2413     *  {@code Stream}.</p>
2414     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2415     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2416     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2417     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
2418     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2419     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2420     *  empty.</p>
2421     *
2422     *  @param  input  The String to split.
2423     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2424     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2425     *
2426     *  @since 0.0.7
2427     */
2428    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2429    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final int separator )
2430    {
2431        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2432        final var codepoints = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).codePoints().toArray();
2433        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2434        var begin = -1;
2435        for( var i = 0 ; i < codepoints.length; ++i )
2436        {
2437            if( begin == -1 )
2438            {
2439                begin = i;
2440            }
2441            if( codepoints [ i ] == separator )
2442            {
2443                builder.add( new String( codepoints, begin, i - begin ).intern() );
2444                begin = -1;
2445            }
2446        }
2447
2448        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2449        if( (begin >= 0) && (begin < codepoints.length) )
2450        {
2451            builder.add( new String( codepoints, begin, codepoints.length - begin ).intern() );
2452        }
2453        if( (codepoints.length == 0) || (codepoints [codepoints.length - 1] == separator) )
2454        {
2455            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2456        }
2457
2458        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2459        final var retValue = builder.build();
2460
2461        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2462        return retValue;
2463    }   //  stream()
2464
2465    /**
2466     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator sequence and
2467     *  returns an instance of
2468     *  {@link Stream}
2469     *  containing all parts.} In case a separator sequence is immediately
2470     *  followed by another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to
2471     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
2472     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2473     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
2474     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty string, as it will end with an
2475     *  empty String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
2476     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2477     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2478     *  empty.</p>
2479     *
2480     *  @param  input   The String to split.
2481     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2482     *  @return The parts of the String.
2483     *
2484     *  @since 0.0.7
2485     */
2486    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2487    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final CharSequence separator )
2488    {
2489        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2490        @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
2491        var s = requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).toString();
2492        @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
2493        final var t = requireNotEmptyArgument( separator, "separator" ).toString();
2494
2495        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2496        var pos = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
2497        while( isNotEmpty( s ) && (pos >= 0) )
2498        {
2499            pos = s.indexOf( t );
2500            switch( Integer.signum( pos ) )
2501            {
2502                case 0 -> /* String starts with separator */
2503                    {
2504                        builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2505                        s = s.substring( t.length() );
2506                    }
2507                case 1 -> /* String contains a separator somewhere */
2508                    {
2509                        builder.add( s.substring( 0, pos ) );
2510                        s = s.substring( pos + t.length() );
2511                    }
2512                default -> { /* Just leave the loop */ }
2513            }   //  ResultHandlerSwitch:
2514        }
2515
2516        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2517        builder.add( s );
2518
2519        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2520        final var retValue = builder.build();
2521
2522        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2523        return retValue;
2524    }   //  stream()
2525
2526    /**
2527     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String using the given regular expression and
2528     *  returns an instance of
2529     *  {@link Stream}
2530     *  providing all parts.} In case a separator sequence is immediately
2531     *  followed by another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to
2532     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
2533     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2534     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
2535     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty string, as it will end with an
2536     *  empty String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
2537     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2538     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2539     *  empty.</p>
2540     *
2541     *  @note This method behaves different from
2542     *      {@link String#split(String)}
2543     *      as it will return trailing empty Strings.
2544     *
2545     *  @param  input  The String to split.
2546     *  @param  pattern The separator sequence.
2547     *  @return The parts of the String.
2548     *
2549     *  @see String#split(String)
2550     *  @see Pattern#split(CharSequence)
2551     *
2552     *  @since 0.0.7
2553     */
2554    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2555    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence input, final Pattern pattern )
2556    {
2557        requireNonNullArgument( pattern, "pattern" );
2558
2559        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2560        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2561        if( isEmpty( requireNonNullArgument( input, "s" ) ) )
2562        {
2563            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2564        }
2565        else
2566        {
2567            final var parts = pattern.split( input );
2568            for( final var part : parts )
2569            {
2570                builder.add( part );
2571            }
2572            final var matcher = pattern.matcher( input );
2573            var count = 0;
2574            while( matcher.find() ) ++count;
2575            //noinspection ForLoopWithMissingComponent
2576            for( ; count >= parts.length; --count )
2577            {
2578                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2579            }
2580        }
2581
2582        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2583        final var retValue = builder.build();
2584
2585        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2586        return retValue;
2587    }   //  stream()
2588
2589    /**
2590     *  Strips HTML or XML tags from the given String, without touching other
2591     *  entities (like {@code &amp;} or {@code &nbsp;}). The result would be
2592     *  the effective text, stripped from all other whitespace (except single
2593     *  blanks).<br>
2594     *  <br>This means that the result for
2595     *  <pre><code>stripTags( &quot;&lt;html&gt;
2596     *      &lt;head&gt;
2597     *        &hellip;
2598     *      &lt;/head&gt;
2599     *      &lt;body&gt;
2600     *        &lt;a href='&hellip;'&gt;       Simple          &lt;br&gt;
2601     *          &lt;br&gt;           Text       &lt;/a&gt;
2602     *      &lt;/body&gt;
2603     *  &lt;/html&gt;&quot; )</code></pre> would be just
2604     *  &quot;{@code Simple Text}&quot;.<br>
2605     *  <br>Comments will be stripped as well, and {@code <pre>} tags are not
2606     *  interpreted, with the consequence that any formatting with whitespace
2607     *  gets lost. {@code CDATA} elements are stripped, too.
2608     *
2609     *  @param  input   The HTML/XML string.
2610     *  @return The string without the tags.
2611     *
2612     *  @since 0.0.7
2613     */
2614    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2615    public static final String stripTags( final CharSequence input )
2616    {
2617        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
2618        if( isNotEmptyOrBlank( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ) ) )
2619        {
2620            final var matcher = m_TagRemovalPattern.matcher( input );
2621            final var buffer = matcher.replaceAll( " " ).trim().codePoints().toArray();
2622            int lastChar = NULL_CHAR;
2623            ScanLoop: for( final var codePoint : buffer )
2624            {
2625                if( isWhitespace( codePoint ) )
2626                {
2627                    //---* Consecutive whitespace detected *-------------------
2628                    if( isWhitespace( lastChar ) ) continue ScanLoop;
2629
2630                    //---* All resulting whitespace have to be blanks *--------
2631                    retValue.append( " " );
2632                }
2633                else
2634                {
2635                    //---* Write the character *-------------------------------
2636                    retValue.append( toChars( codePoint ) );
2637                }
2638                lastChar = codePoint;
2639            }   //  ScanLoop:
2640        }
2641
2642        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2643        return retValue.toString();
2644    }   //  stripTags()
2645
2646    /**
2647     *  <p>{@summary Strips characters from the given input that are not
2648     *  allowed (or should be at least avoided) for a file or folder name on
2649     *  most or all operating systems.}</p>
2650     *  <p>The following characters will be stripped:</p>
2651     *  <dl>
2652     *  <dt><b>:</b> (colon)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used to separate
2653     *  the drive letter from the path and file name; on Unix-like operating
2654     *  systems (including MacOS) it would be valid, but it can cause issues on
2655     *  the {@code PATH} and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on these operating
2656     *  systems.</dd>
2657     *  <dt><b>\</b> (backslash)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used as the
2658     *  path separator, while on Unix-like operating systems it is problematic
2659     *  in other ways. For example, it is used to escape blanks in not-quoted
2660     *  file or folder names.</dd>
2661     *  <dt><b>/</b> (slash or forward slash)</dt><dd>The path separator on
2662     *  Unix-like operating systems, but Java will use it that way on Windows
2663     *  systems, too.</dd>
2664     *  <dt><b>;</b> (semicolon)</dt><dd>It can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2665     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on Windows.</dd>
2666     *  <dt><b>*</b> (asterisk)</dt><dd>The asterisk is often used as wild card
2667     *  character in shell programs to find groups of files; using it in a file
2668     *  name can cause funny effects.</dd>
2669     *  <dt><b>?</b> (question mark)</dt><dd>The question mark is used on
2670     *  Windows as a wild card for a single character; similar to the asterisk,
2671     *  it can cause funny effects when used in a file name.</dd>
2672     *  <dt><b>&quot;</b> (double quotes)</dt>
2673     *  <dt><b>'</b> (single quotes)</dt><dd>Both have some potential to
2674     *  confuse the various shell programs of all operating systems.</dd>
2675     *  <dt><b>@</b> ('at'-sign)</dt><dd>Although it is allowed for file and
2676     *  folder names, it causes issues when used in the URL for that respective
2677     *  file.</dd>
2678     *  <dt><b>|</b> (pipe symbol)</dt><dd>Similar to the '*' (asterisk), the
2679     *  pipe-symbol has â as the name already indicates - a meaning on most
2680     *  shells that would make it difficult to manage files that contains this
2681     *  character in their names.</dd>
2682     *  <dt><b>&lt;</b> (less than)</dt>
2683     *  <dt><b>&gt;</b> (greater than)</dt><dd>Like the pipe, these two have a
2684     *  meaning on most shells that would make it difficult to manage files
2685     *  that contains one of these characters in their names.</dd>
2686     *  <dt>Whitespace</dt><dd>Only blanks will remain, any other whitespace
2687     *  characters are stripped.</dd>
2688     *  </dl>
2689     *  <p>Finally, the method will strip all leading and trailing blanks;
2690     *  although blanks are usually allowed, they are confusing when not
2691     *  surrounded by some visible characters.</p>
2692     *  <p>Especially regarding the characters that are critical for shells
2693     *  ('*', '?', '&quot;', ''', '|', '&lt;', and '&gt;') this method is
2694     *  over-cautious, as most shells could handle them after proper escaping
2695     *  the offending characters or quoting the file name.</p>
2696     *  <p>This method furthermore assumes that any other Unicode character is
2697     *  valid for a file or folder name; unfortunately, there are filesystems
2698     *  where this is not true.</p>
2699     *
2700     *  @note   This method will not take care about the length of the returned
2701     *      String; this means the result to a call to this method may still be
2702     *      invalid as a file or folder name because it is too long.
2703     *
2704     *  @param  input   The input String, denoting a file or folder name -
2705     *      <i>not</i> a full path.
2706     *  @return The String without the characters that are invalid for a file
2707     *      name. This value will never be {@code null} or empty.
2708     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The input is {@code null}.
2709     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  The input is the empty String.
2710     *  @throws ValidationException After stripping the invalid characters the
2711     *      return value would be empty.
2712     *
2713     *  @since 0.0.5
2714     */
2715    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
2716    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2717    public static final String stripToFilename( final CharSequence input ) throws ValidationException
2718    {
2719        final var len = requireNotEmptyArgument( input, "input" ).length();
2720        final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len );
2721        ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
2722        {
2723            final var currentCharacter = input.charAt( i );
2724            Selector:
2725            //noinspection SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches,EnhancedSwitchMigration
2726            switch( currentCharacter )
2727            {
2728                case ':':
2729                case '\\':
2730                case '/':
2731                case ';':
2732                case '*':
2733                case '"':
2734                case '\'':
2735                case '@':
2736                case '|':
2737                case '?':
2738                case '<':
2739                case '>':
2740                    continue ScanLoop;
2741
2742                default:
2743                {
2744                    if( (currentCharacter == ' ') || (!isISOControl( currentCharacter ) && !isWhitespace( currentCharacter )) )
2745                    {
2746                        buffer.append( currentCharacter );
2747                    }
2748                    break Selector;
2749                }
2750            }   //  Selector:
2751        }   //  ScanLoop:
2752
2753        final var retValue = buffer.toString().trim();
2754        if( retValue.isEmpty() )
2755        {
2756            throw new ValidationException( "After stripping the invalid characters from '%1$s' there do not remain enough characters for a valid file name".formatted(  input.toString() ) );
2757        }
2758
2759        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2760        return retValue;
2761    }   //  stripToFilename()
2762
2763    /**
2764     *  Strips HTML or XML comments from the given String.
2765     *
2766     *  @param  input   The HTML/XML string.
2767     *  @return The string without the comments.
2768     *
2769     *  @since 0.0.5
2770     */
2771    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2772    public static final String stripXMLComments( final CharSequence input )
2773    {
2774        final var matcher = m_CommentRemovalPattern.matcher( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ) );
2775        final var retValue = matcher.replaceAll( EMPTY_STRING );
2776
2777        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2778        return retValue;
2779    }   //  stripXMLComments()
2780
2781    /**
2782     *  Translates the given String to a String that will only contain
2783     *  printable ASCII characters; all other characters will be 'escaped' to
2784     *  the format &quot;&#92;uXXXX&quot;.
2785     *
2786     *  @param  input   The input string; may be {@code null}.
2787     *  @return The output string; {@code null} if the input string was
2788     *      already {@code null}.
2789     *
2790     *  @since 0.0.5
2791     *  @deprecated Use instead
2792     *      {@link CharSetUtils#convertUnicodeToASCII(java.text.Normalizer.Form, CharSequence)}
2793     *      with
2794     *      {@link java.text.Normalizer.Form#NFKC}
2795     *      as the first argument.
2796     */
2797    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2798    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2799    public static final String toUnicode( final CharSequence input )
2800    {
2801        return CharSetUtils.convertUnicodeToASCII( NFKC, input );
2802    }   //  toUnicode()
2803
2804    /**
2805     *  Changes the first letter of the given String tolower case as per
2806     *  {@link Character#toLowerCase(char)}.
2807     *  No other letters are changed. A {@code null} input String returns
2808     *  {@code null}.<br>
2809     *  <br>Samples:<pre><code>  StringUtils.uncapitalize( null ) = null;
2810     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;&quot;)     = &quot;&quot;;
2811     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;Cat&quot;)  = &quot;cat&quot;;
2812     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;CAT&quot;)  = &quot;cAT&quot;;</code></pre>
2813     *  <br>Basically, this is the complementary method to
2814     *  {@link #capitalize(CharSequence)}.
2815     *  Use this method to normalise the name of bean attributes.
2816     *
2817     *  @param  input   The String to <i>uncapitalise</i>, may be {@code null}.
2818     *  @return The <i>uncapitalised</i> String, {@code null} if the argument
2819     *      was {@code null}.
2820     *  @see #capitalize(CharSequence)
2821     *
2822     *  @since 0.0.5
2823     *  @deprecated Use
2824     *      {@link #decapitalize(CharSequence)}
2825     *      instead.
2826     */
2827    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
2828    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0" )
2829    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2830    public static final String uncapitalize( final CharSequence input ) { return decapitalize( input ); }
2831
2832    /**
2833     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2834     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes. Supports HTML
2835     *  5.0 entities.<br>
2836     *  <br>For example, the string
2837     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2838     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2839     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2840     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2841     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2842     *
2843     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2844     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2845     *      string was already {@code null}.
2846     *
2847     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2848     *  @see #escapeHTML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2849     *
2850     *  @since 0.0.5
2851     */
2852    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2853    public static final String unescapeHTML( final CharSequence input )
2854    {
2855        final var retValue = nonNull( input ) ? HTML50.unescape( input ) : null;
2856
2857        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2858        return retValue;
2859    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2860
2861    /**
2862     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2863     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes and writes it to
2864     *  the given
2865     *  {@link Appendable}.
2866     *  Supports HTML 4.0 entities.<br>
2867     *  <br>For example, the string
2868     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2869     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2870     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2871     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2872     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2873     *
2874     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2875     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2876     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
2877     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2878     *
2879     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2880     *
2881     *  @since 0.0.5
2882     */
2883    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2884    public static final void unescapeHTML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence input ) throws IOException
2885    {
2886        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2887
2888        if( nonNull( input ) ) HTML50.unescape( appendable, input );
2889    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2890
2891    /**
2892     *  Parses Strings in the format &quot;<code>&#92;uXXXX</code>&quot;,
2893     *  containing the textual representation of a single Unicode character, to
2894     *  the respective Unicode character. Some Unicode characters will be
2895     *  represented as <i>surrogate pairs</i> in Java, so the String that is
2896     *  returned by this method may contain more than one {@code char}.<br>
2897     *  <br>The input format for this method is used in Java source code
2898     *  Strings, in Java {@code .properties} files, in C/C++ source code, in
2899     *  JavaScript source, &hellip;
2900     *
2901     *  @param  input   The input String with the Unicode escape sequence.
2902     *  @return The Unicode character.
2903     *  @throws ValidationException The input is {@code null}, empty, or cannot
2904     *      be parsed as a unicode escape sequence.
2905     *
2906     *  @since 0.0.5
2907     *  @deprecated Use
2908     *      {@link CharSetUtils#unescapeUnicode(CharSequence)}
2909     *      instead.
2910     */
2911    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
2912    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2913    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2914    public static final String unescapeUnicode( final CharSequence input )
2915    {
2916        return CharSetUtils.unescapeUnicode( input );
2917    }   //  unescapeUnicode()
2918
2919    /**
2920     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML string containing XML entity escapes to a
2921     *  string containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2922     *  escapes.}</p>
2923     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2924     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2925     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2926     *
2927     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2928     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2929     *      string was already {@code null}.
2930     *
2931     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2932     *  @see #escapeXML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2933     *
2934     *  @since 0.0.5
2935     */
2936    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2937    public static final String unescapeXML( final CharSequence input )
2938    {
2939        final var retValue = nonNull( input ) ? XML.unescape( input ) : null;
2940
2941        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2942        return retValue;
2943    }   //  unescapeXML()
2944
2945    /**
2946     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML String containing XML entity escapes to a
2947     *  String containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2948     *  escapes and writes it to the given
2949     *  {@link Appendable}.}</p>
2950     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2951     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2952     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2953     *
2954     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2955     *  @param  input   The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2956     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The writer is {@code null}.
2957     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2958     *
2959     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2960     *
2961     *  @since 0.0.5
2962     */
2963    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2964    public static final void unescapeXML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence input ) throws IOException
2965    {
2966        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2967
2968        if( nonNull( input ) ) XML.unescape( appendable, input );
2969    }   //  unescapeXML()

2971    /**
2972     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given character. This will
2973     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2974     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2975     *
2976     *  @param  c   The character.
2977     *  @return The escape sequence.
2978     *
2979     *  @deprecated Use
2980     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(char)}
2981     *      instead.
2982     *
2983     *  @since 0.0.5
2984     */
2985    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2986    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2987    public static final String unicodeEscape( final char c ) { return escapeCharacter( c ); }
2988
2989    /**
2990     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given code point. This will
2991     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2992     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2993     *
2994     *  @param  codePoint   The character.
2995     *  @return The escape sequence.
2996     *
2997     *  @deprecated Use
2998     *      {@link #escapeUnicode(int)}
2999     *      instead.
3000     *
3001     *  @since 0.0.5
3002     */
3003    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
3004    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
3005    public static final String unicodeEscape( final int codePoint ) { return escapeUnicode( codePoint ); }
3006
3007    /**
3008     *  Returns the given URL encoded String in its decoded form, using the
3009     *  UTF-8 character encoding.<br>
3010     *  <br>Internally, this method and
3011     *  {@link #urlEncode(CharSequence)}
3012     *  make use of the methods from
3013     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder}
3014     *  and
3015     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder}, respectively. The methods here were
3016     *  introduced to simplify the handling, as first only the UTF-8 encoding
3017     *  should be used - making the second argument for the methods
3018     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String) decode()}/
3019     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String) encode()}
3020     *  obsolete - and second, they could throw an
3021     *  {@link UnsupportedEncodingException} - although this should never occur
3022     *  when UTF-8 encoding is used.
3023     *
3024     *  @param  input   The input String.
3025     *  @return The decoded result.
3026     *
3027     *  @see java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String)
3028     *
3029     *  @since 0.0.5
3030     */
3031    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
3032    public static final String urlDecode( final CharSequence input )
3033    {
3034        final var retValue = decode( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).toString(), UTF8 );
3035
3036        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
3037        return retValue;
3038    }   //  urlDecode()
3039
3040    /**
3041     *  Returns the given String in its URL encoded form, using the
3042     *  UTF-8 character encoding.
3043     *
3044     *  @param  input   The input String.
3045     *  @return The URL encoded result.
3046     *
3047     *  @see java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String)
3048     *  @see #urlDecode(CharSequence)
3049     *
3050     *  @since 0.0.5
3051     */
3052    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
3053    public static final String urlEncode( final CharSequence input )
3054    {
3055        final var retValue = encode( requireNonNullArgument( input, "input" ).toString(), UTF8 );
3056
3057        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
3058        return retValue;
3059    }   //  urlEncode()
3060}
